I'm new to the list, so I apologize if this topic has been hashed over
before. I tried searching the archives, but found nothing applicable. If
this is an old topic, I would appreciate a pointer to the thread...

 

Background:

I have written several derivatives of java.io.InputStream and test cases
that go along with them. However, during a recent peer review of the
code, we discovered an inconsistency between the contract of one of the
methods in java.io.InputStream and my implementation of that same method
in the specialized subclass.

 

Problem:

I would like to have a set of functional tests (black-box style) that
enforce the behaviors of the super class, java.io.InputStream. Then use
that same set of tests to ensure that the basic contracts for each of
the classes I write follow that contract (i.e. pass those generic
tests). Does anyone have a suggestion for doing this? While this
specific example pertains to java.io.InputStream the same scenario may
occur with any class hierarchy.

 

Environment:

I use Ant to compile and run my tests, so ideally any solution will be
compatible with the <batchtest> mechanism or otherwise allow for the
dynamic (read, "automatic") addition of new tests.

 

Thanks,

 

Josh
